stage1.title: Lunch Buddies
stage1.opening: You are a university student. Your cohort mate and girlfriend, Mary, is studying with you today in school. It’s 2.08pm, and the both of you just returned from lunch.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: That meal was so filling I might get a food coma soon.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Oh man, looks like today is going to be unproductive.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: So how much was it? I’ll eTransfer you.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: It’s fine. I’ll pay today.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Wow, why’s that?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: You deserve a treat for doing well for your quiz.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Thank you!

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: No worries.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Do you even have enough money for the rest of the month?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Uh- I try to spend less.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: But I’ve seen you going out frequently with Jay, Sean and the other guy.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: His name is Peter.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yeah, him. You’re not working part time too right?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Nope. I just use my savings for now.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You might not last long with the way you’re spending, John.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Well, what about you? How do you spend?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: I try to limit my spending on wants, like branded items.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Isn’t your wallet and bag is from Yucha?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yeah, but those are birthday gifts from my family. Doesn’t count.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: What about going out with friends?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: I do hang out quite often, but I don’t spend much. It’s possible.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Interesting. Anyway, I will also need to pay for my hostel and tuition fees.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Your parents are not paying for you?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I told him I’ll settle them myself first.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: But you don’t have a lot of money, right?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah. I need to reconsider how I spend.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You can part-time. Teach tuition. Work F&B. Whatever.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I have other commitments in school too.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Oh right. Community Service Club and Ultimate Frisbee.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’ll see what I can do then. Time to continue work.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yeah, my assignment is due in 2 days.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Same.

stage1.decision: er time, you wonder about your financial status. “Is there anything I can do?” You ask yourself as you spend another graceless night with your friends. Eventually, you decide to...

options.desc: Look for a part-time job
options.outcome: You found a tuition gig that pays really well. You finally have some income but you still decided to heed Mary’s suggestion to spend less on wants. You feel better offloading some burden off your parents while still being self-sufficient, although you had to struggle with studies and other commitments.

options.desc: Cut down on your spending.
options.outcome: You decided to reduce your spending on wants. Your friends judge your frugality. You told them that you wanted to save more since you’re not earning money. You don’t feel so bad now that you spend less than before, even though you still miss getting drinks and late night supper.

options.desc: Continue living life as usual.
options.outcome: You carry on living and spending your money with your good friends, sometimes even on yourself. Time passes, and you occasionally fear not having enough money to fund your entire university course. The worst that could happen is asking your parents for money.

stage1.title: Graduation Trip
stage1.opening: You and Mary have finally graduated with good Honours degrees. As such, you plan to go on a graduation trip with her. One evening, you both take a walk along Orchard Road.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: How about Prince Rae’s Town? I love how artistic the place feels.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Ah, it looks better in winter. Not now.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Right. It’s probably crowded during this peak period too.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: What about Mory Islands? (points) Apparently that shop originated from there.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Oh, I’ve read that in the news too. It’s not as popular yet.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: We can travel around the area too.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Would 10 days be enough?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Maybe 12. We could spend a few days up in the hills.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Nice. I’ll source for flight tickets too.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: And insurance.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Travel insurance?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yeah. Insurance is a must-have. You’re still under Doricane Healthcare right?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: That one’s for medical coverage.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: We need to get travel insurance too.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Well, if you keep your items safe and sound…

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: It doesn’t work that way, John.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I find it a waste of money.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You’re paying for coverage. Think protection.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’ll protect you.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Don’t be gross. There are cheap ones out there.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Then I’ll get them.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Usually the more you pay, the greater your coverage.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Logically.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: So you’ll be settling all these for the trip?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Can you think of what else to do there?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Snorkelling, surfing, hiking. There’s so much to do.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yes, we have 12 days.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: We’ll have lots of fun there.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: More fun than strolling along this sad street.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Hey! You agreed to this.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Just kidding!

stage1.decision: u return home and excitedly plan for the trip. Towards the finalisation, you remembered the travel insurance Mary kept insisting you to buy. You decide to...

options.desc: Get the higher-end insurance that covers a multitude of travel issues.
options.outcome: You bought travel insurance that covers you and Mary greatly. Mary was surprised by your change in mentality. Though expensive, you and Mary were enabled to travel fearlessly to Mory Islands and participate in a variety of activities, like scuba diving and gliding. She felt that it was the best trip she had so far.

options.desc: Get the lower-end insurance that provides basic travel coverage.
options.outcome: You bought the basic travel insurance that provides the minimum protection. You didn’t spend too much on it, and so you use most of your money on the actual trip. Mary enjoyed the trip very much, as it was her first time participating in many of the water sport activities.

options.desc: Not get any travel insurance and save the money instead.
options.outcome: You chose not to get any travel insurance. Mary was a little upset at you but as the trip progressed, she gradually forgot about it and immersed herself in the activities on the Islands. Unfortunately, there was a delay in flight on the way back. Without insurance, the both of you reluctantly spend another night there.

stage1.title: What’s your appetite?

dialogue.name: Waiter
dialogue.text: Good evening, Sir. May I take your order? (Takes up his notebook and pen)

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Hi. Can we get the Signature OmuRice Set and the Ultimate-- Omama Set?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: (laughs) It’s Omu-Ma.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yes! That.

dialogue.name: Waiter
dialogue.text: Okay, and your drinks?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’ll have Ice Lemon Tea, and.. (signals to Mary)

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Passionfruit tea for me.

dialogue.name: Waiter
dialogue.text: Got it. Anything else?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: No, thank you.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Omama.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I have no words. But I have things to ask you.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yes Mr. Omama?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’ve been thinking about how to fund our future.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You mean like buying a car? Condo? Our wedding?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah, all those. I realised we don’t have that much money.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Mmm. Have you considered investments?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah. Peter did mention to me about it before.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Did he mention the different types?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: He said I could invest in low-risk unit trusts or high-risk individual stocks.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: They all come with different risk levels and potential returns.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: It all depends on my risk appetite.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Hmm.. seems like you don’t know much about investments.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Sadly, yeah.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: But how hungry are you to fulfill those financial goals?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (stomach growls) … More than my want to eat OmuRice.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Sounds alot. But if you need the money urgently, we can always loan from the bank.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Or use our savings first.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yeah, why not.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: So many options, huh. I guess I’ll go consider my various options.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Don’t worry too much. You’ll find your answer.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yes, Mrs Omama.

stage1.decision: u went home satisfied. That was probably the best OmuRice you had in ages. As you crept into bed, you pondered about how to meet your financial goals. You decide to…

options.desc: Use your savings and take a loan.
options.outcome: You withdrew most of your savings to fund your wedding and took a heavy loan to fund a condominium. Because of that, the interest compounded was rather great, and you took many years to clear the debt. Nonetheless, you were looking forward to the wedding and the condominium.

options.desc: Invest in high-risk stocks.
options.outcome: You bought some high-risk stocks without much financial knowledge. Nobody knows about it except you. Weeks later, you were notified of the closure of the company you invested in. Because you weren’t keeping an eye on the market, it crashed before you could sell your stocks.

options.desc: Invest in low to medium risk instruments.
options.outcome: You chose to invest in stocks that were relatively low-risk. The potential returns weren’t too much, but such investment was suitable given your own financial knowledge. Online advisors and guides assisted you along the way. You watch your investments grow slowly but steadily.

stage2.title: Cars Cars Cars
stage2.opening: You work for Toshki Inc as a sales manager. One weekend, you accompanied your friend Peter to an automobile show, one with “wheel-y” big discounts. Peter hands you a brochure.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: See, that’s the best deal in this entire show. The Tasel 3X5!

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: So this is how it looks like.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: This model runs on clean energy too. More expensive, but lower maintenance costs.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: So you save in the long run?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Exactly.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Sounds worth it.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: I think you should consider getting one. Your place isn’t near your house anyway.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (Sighs) Well I do have a driving license.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Or maybe a more affordable but functional brand? Like Toyata.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Maybe a second-hand one.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Hey, second-hand just means higher maintenance cost.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: … Do you actually know what you want to get, Peter?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Either the Tasel or the Jaguava. Definitely the best deal this century!

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: And how are you going to pay for it?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: I can afford the downpayment. They say you can haggle for 15%.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: And the interest?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Depends on the seller, usually between 2-3%.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Hmm..

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: But it’s around the same here. Just find what you like most.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I kinda fine with public transport though.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Yeah, but since I brought you here, might as well get a good deal for yourself.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Oh! Isn’t that the Jaguava?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: You bet. Some say it provides the best comfort and technical features.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Interesting.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: You don’t sound interested.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’m just considering my options.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: So you might actually get one!

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I have to think about how to finance it too.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Ah. Wise man, but remember that these discounts will probably not happen again.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: How sure are you?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: About 8-- Wait, that’s the Tasel!

stage2.decision: ter eventually purchased the Tasel and urged you to consider getting one too. “You won’t regret it,” Peter said as you watched him hand over his credit card. As the automobile show was on for another 2 days, you decided to give it a thought. You choose to…

options.desc: Not get any car.
options.outcome: You decided that public transport was alright, so you didn’t spend money on any car. Occasionally it fails you, but on the whole it has been efficient. Every now and then, Peter would give you a hitch in his new Tasel 3X5 and give a lecture on why getting a car is the best decision one could ever make.

options.desc: Get a second-hand but lower-brand car.
options.outcome: You decided to purchase a second-hand Toyata. It didn’t save you much time because of peak hour traffic jams, and it wasn’t the most comfortable either. It was usable, and getting around the city was much easier. You paid the down payment of 15% and paid the rest in monthly instalments, with a surprising 3.5% interest.

options.desc: Get the Tasel too.
options.outcome: You got the Tasel the following day. Peter’s persuasion was convincing and you believed that getting one was worth it. Down payment was 20%, which set you back quite a bit. With the high marked price and 3% interest, you had quite a struggle funding instalments as well. “You won’t regret it,” you replay again in your head.

stage2.title: Inheritance
stage2.opening: You’re in your middle age now, married with two kids: Elsa (7) and Chris (5). Mary went out earlier to run her usual errands. It’s 9.35pm and you’re putting the kids to bed.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: (arrives last) Wow. That was such a long queue for a plate of Hokkien Mee!

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Well, it probably good then.

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: Do you guys want drinks? I’m getting a Teh Bing.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: Teh Alia Bing.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Teh Bing too.

dialogue.name: Karen
dialogue.text: Kopi O Kosong Bing.

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: (looks around) Ah Uncle! I want a …

dialogue.name: Karen
dialogue.text: So how was your holiday, Rachel? Got see scenery anot?

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: Yeah of course! The Moon Dust River was so chio!

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: Thanks Uncle. Yeah, did you go to that famous town?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Prince Rae’s Town! I heard the place looks like an artwork.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: We did! That was on our second day though. The kids became tired so quickly.

dialogue.name: Karen
dialogue.text: Aiya.. kids like that one.

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: So John, when will it be your turn?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Don’t know. When I get enough money.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: You say as if you’re broke. Why not go travel with Mary this summer!

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: Or save that money and buy a car.

dialogue.name: Karen
dialogue.text: Cars nowadays very expensive.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (head) I guess I do have $50,000.

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: And nowadays you need a car to travel around. The MRTs unreliable one.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: John, I know you haven’t been to Prince Rae’s.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: I tell you, you can spend 2 days there and it won’t be enough.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Don’t know leh. I need to check when Mary’s free.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: I’m sure Mary will love it. You were saying you promised to bring her on a trip?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah, but she’s always busy with her Pilates and cooking sessions.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: So that she can cook your dinner next time. No need to go out.

dialogue.name: Oliver
dialogue.text: Can ask her cook for Toshki’s D&D also?

dialogue.name: Karen
dialogue.text: Crazy. Anyway, if you ever have a lot of money, remember to save and invest some.

dialogue.name: Rachel
dialogue.text: Actually, working in this company taught me to spend more and make myself happier.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah. Maybe I’ll think about what to do with my inheritance.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Huh? I mean I’ll go think about it. Nothing much.

dialogue.name: Chris
dialogue.text: Daddy, is Santa Claus real?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (covers Chris with a blanket) As real as you want him to be.

dialogue.name: Elsa
dialogue.text: My friend said Santa Claus is fake.

dialogue.name: Chris
dialogue.text: My friend said he saw him before.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Okay, it’s past bedtime. Go to sleep.

dialogue.name: Chris
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Cover yourself with the blanket, Elsa.

dialogue.name: Elsa
dialogue.text: But Daddy I-

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Shh.. No more noise. Goodnight.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Dear, there’s a letter for you. From Doricane Healthcare. The kids asleep?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (opens letter) Yeah, I just tucked them in. How are you?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Bad. The weather’s so humid even at night. So what does it say?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: It says my Integrated Shield Plan is expiring in a month’s time.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Oh that one. Are you going to renew it?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Maybe. Medical insurance for private hospitals are so expensive though.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You can try government hospitals instead. They’re cheaper.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: On top of MediShield Life that provides basic protection against high hospital bills?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Yes. You may want to get another one to supplement MediShield.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Actually I haven’t gone for any surgery.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: It doesn’t mean that you don’t need coverage.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I haven’t been greatly sick!

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You never know when you might need it.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: But honey I-

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Shh.. the kids are sleeping.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I know. My bad.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: At least get the Class B1 coverage for government hospitals.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’ll go think about it. The premiums are higher for me now.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Insurance is a must-have, honey.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: So is a healthy lifestyle.

stage2.decision: ter settling the other mails, you watched another episode of “Vanity Lab” before preparing to sleep. You thought about your medical insurance, and decide to...

options.desc: Travel with Mary
options.outcome: You decide to take Mary on a long-awaited trip to the Land of Prince Rae. She appreciated it greatly and enjoyed the trip, and so did yourself. You finally got to visit the famous town there and got souvenirs for your office.

options.desc: Invest the money
options.outcome: You decided to invest most of the money into low to medium-risk stocks, hoping it would give you better returns. You chose the stocks carefully, since you were still new to investing. To your excitement, you made a profit.

options.desc: Save all the money
options.outcome: You saved up the rest of the money, putting it in your savings account and watched its growth over the years. Saving was important, but it didn’t give you much returns, to your discontent.

options.desc: Extend the insurance for private hospitals.
options.outcome: You extended your Integrated Shield Plan for Doricane Healthcare. Mary was glad you decided to continue your own coverage. You pay higher premiums because of your relatively older age and private hospital benefits. Nonetheless, you continue to stay healthy and exercise once in a while.

options.desc: Switch to a coverage for government hospitals Class B1.
options.outcome: You bought a new and cheaper coverage for government hospitals. Mary was glad you got yourself covered. She too was under the same coverage, and believed that Class B1 is good enough. Your premiums are relatively cheaper, but that doesn’t stop you from continuing to adopt a healthy lifestyle.

options.desc: Live only with the basic MediShield Plan
options.outcome: You refrained from getting another insurance plan because you didn’t think you would need it. Because of this, you feared doing activities that might cost you injuries, since you were only covered on the basic level. You rather spend time on developing a healthy lifestyle than pay premiums.

stage3.title: Allocation of Resources
stage3.opening: It’s 1.34pm. The sky is clear. Mary is out at a tupperware party. The hit docu-series “Frugal Families” is playing on your 55” Smart TV.

dialogue.name: TV
dialogue.text: … Like Chen Li, many of us don’t know how to properly spend our money.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Maybe I should think about how to properly allocate my finances now that I’ve retired.

dialogue.name: TV
dialogue.text: Chen Li’s favourite designer brand is Louis Vuitton.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Peter’s probably the best person to ask about this.

dialogue.name: TV
dialogue.text: He has a room full of prized collections that he calls his “baby vuittons”.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (Calls Peter on the phone)

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Hi, Johnny. What a weird timing. What’s up?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Nothing much. Watching your favourite TV show.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: “Heaven’s Demons?!”

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Nah, “Frugal Families”.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Pfft. You’re one to kid. I’m actually busy now. Grandpa things, you know?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah, just wanted to ask for some financial advice.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Like what?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Like how much to spend. How much to save.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: So far I’ve just gone along with my gut feeling.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Looks like it took decades for you to start thinking about budget allocation.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Peter...

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Okay, okay. It depends on you.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: That’s such a cliche.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: I know, but it’s true. Personally I follow the 80-20 rule.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: 20% goes towards your financial goals, like paying off your remaining debts.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: The other 80% can be used for anything.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: That works for retirement right?

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Yeah, but everything is just a guideline though.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Some people follow the 50-30-20 rule, where 80% is further broken down.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: 50% is for necessities like electricity and phone bills, and the other 30% is for wants.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah, I can ask Mary about it too.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: She’s your wife, not your finance secretary.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Or maybe you want to continue living with your ‘gut feeling’.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Maybe. Well, thanks for the advise, Peter. Appreciate it.

dialogue.name: Peter
dialogue.text: Anything for you, buddy. See you another time.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yup! (hangs up)

dialogue.name: TV
dialogue.text: Currently in debt, Chen Li has a hard time managing his finances.

dialogue.name: TV
dialogue.text: Abandoned by his own children, he has only his “baby vuittons” to keep him company.

stage3.decision: u turn off the TV after that episode ended. You don’t want to end up like Chen Li, although you don’t buy branded goods. As such, you decide to…

options.desc: Spend and save as you feel suitable.
options.outcome: The months go by, and you spend your retirement savings as you wish. Whatever remains depletes quickly. Living without proper budget allocation, you decide that taking Mary out for dinners and spending on entertainment is more important than anything else.

options.desc: Follow the 50-30-20 rule.
options.outcome: You follow the 50-30-20 rule. It started off troublesome to keep track of your expenses, but as time went by, you got the hang of it. You could tell when you were exceeding budget without calculating. One time you passed by an electronics sale, but resisted the urge to get that $799 Grandplayer Set.

options.desc: Go with the 80-20 rule.
options.outcome: You decided to follow the 80-20 rule. Paying off your financial debts became your top priority, and 20% of your monthly expenses went toward it. The rest you decided to spend with Mary, after settling home bills, of course. 80% was a lot to manage, but you promised yourself to keep within the limit.

stage3.title: Central Provident Fund
stage3.opening: Your children have all grown up and have their own families and houses. Your 55th birthday is coming soon, and Mary just got back from her yoga class. 3

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: (closes the door) Wow. You’re early and changed.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Boss left early today.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You sure you didn’t sneak out of office?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Maybe.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Well, what do you want to eat for dinner?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Let’s go to Teck Lee’s. I’m craving for some laksa.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Sure, just let me get changed.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You know I was talking to Megan during yoga.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: She says her husband keeps spending his CPF payouts on toto.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (whispers) Can’t blame a gambler.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You’re going to be 55 next week.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah, CPF sent me a booklet recently, about withdrawals and payouts.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: (pulls up her shorts) Have you decided what to do already?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Nope. I checked my CPF status on the way back from work.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: It says I can withdraw a lump-sum or leave it.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: (closes her drawers) I think you should leave it and let it accumulate.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You have a lot of current savings anyway.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Does it really matter?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: The interest rates in CPF are much higher than average.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You also get a higher monthly payout at 65 if you top up your retirement account.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: How do you know all these?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You meet all kinds of people at yoga.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’m sure you do.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: There’s this auntie today who kept complaining her CPF. Poor her.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (whispers) Can’t blame a boomer.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: What’s that?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Nothing. Can’t wait for laksa.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: (ties her ponytail) Okay. I’m done!

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: (gets out of sofa) Alright. I’m starving!

stage3.decision: at night, feeling full after your favourite bowl of laksa, you thought about what to do with your CPF. You decided to…

options.desc: Withdraw partial amounts in the hundreds every month from your CPF account.
options.outcome: For the next few years, you take out around $500 per month to supplement your income. Sometimes you would use the money to go on short vacations with Mary. Sometimes you take the money and treat yourself to another bowl of laksa. You didn’t need the money, in fact. But you were definitely more happy spending a little more than usual.

options.desc: Withdraw a lump-sum of $20,000 to spend.
options.outcome: You withdraw $20,000 out of the blue. Mary asks why you needed the money. You said that you really wanted to get new kitchen appliances for the house. But actually you were secretly paying off some of the housing debts. Unbeknownst, you got scammed of $500 buying “futuristic fridges” from r200.com.

options.desc: Leave your CPF as it is.
options.outcome: You leave all your CPF savings in the account. You didn’t need the money. You were glad to find the higher interest rates for the accounts as stated on the CPF booklet, just as Mary said. “The interest earned would be worth it,” you told yourself, “and maybe I could get extra ham in my laksa with that.”

stage3.title: To retire or not to retire?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: How’s your back, honey? (Gently places Yangzhou fried rice in front of John)

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Not doing so good. Sometimes when I commute for too long, it hurts.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You should take care of yourself.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah. It’s just us two now that the kids have all grown up.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: They seldom visit us either.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: They’re probably busy, especially Elsa.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Do you plan to retire?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Why the sudden question?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: I’m afraid for you.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I don’t know… when I feel like it?

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: When you’re bedridden and it’s too late?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: You know what I mean.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Honey, you’re not too far from retirement age, you know that right?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Yeah yeah yeah. 62. Or is it 63? Peter told me this just this morning.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Dementia now?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Come on! I was the best at remembering our children’s birthdays.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: 7th January and… 19th March!

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Regardless, you really need to think about retiring, dear.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: You need time to take better care of yourself.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Besides, we have enough money.

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: I’ll consider. Don’t worry about me.

dialogue.name: Mary
dialogue.text: Good. How’s my fried rice?

dialogue.name: John
dialogue.text: Sweeter than honey.

stage3.decision: u realised you have been overworked recently but still have the determination to work longer. You considered your options. Eventually, you decide to…

options.desc: Retire within the year.
options.outcome: You retire at 60. You let out a huge sigh of relief on your last day as fellow colleagues came to wish you a happy retirement. You bring all your gifts and hand-written letters back to your apartment, taking smaller steps than before so as not to worsen your knee pains. If not for Mary, you would probably be working until your death.

options.desc: Retire when you hit the retirement age (62).
options.outcome: You retire at 62. Your back condition worsens although you made more money for you and your spouse. “Was it worth it?” You asked yourself. Your boss gave you the firmest handshake since your first day and smiled so sincerely as he wished you goodbye. Mary welcomed you back home with her signature Yangzhou Fried Rice.

options.desc: Retire at 67.
options.outcome: You retire at 67. Your knees and back sometimes cause quick moments of agony. You wished life was easier. You saved more money for retirement, but can’t help to think when Mary insisted you to retire early. Nobody in the office truly recognised your efforts because of major restructuring.
